image.altText: An illustration of a SARS-CoV-2 virus particle showing the protruding spike proteins on the virus's surface.

items.synopsis: A COVID-19 variant nicknamed "Eris" — after the Greek goddess of chaos, strife and discord — has been in the news after spreading overseas. But the variant has actually been in Australia for four months.

title.children: The ‘goddess of chaos’ COVID variant is making headlines, but it’s been lurking quietly for months

image.altText: A close shot of Mr Butler's face, looking serious.

items.synopsis: The government is negotiating to get enough support to prevent the Coalition from using the Senate to unwind its planned 60-day pharmacy scripts, which would halve the cost of hundreds of medicines.

title.children: Government scrambles to block Coalition's attempt to unwind half-price medication scheme

image.altText: A barge at a port

items.synopsis: The British government says it's trying to "stop the boats", but one of its solutions — a giant, grey barge designed to house 500 asylum seekers — is proving controversial.

title.children: There's a floating 'recipe for disaster' off England's coast — it has links to Australia

image.altText: Actors.

items.synopsis: In India, the Modi government is accused of waging a war on Bollywood and using it for party propaganda.

title.children: 'You have to suck up or shut up': The clampdown on Bollywood's unforgivable sin

image.altText: Filipino marines standing on the deck of a rusty ship.

items.synopsis: For decades the Philippines have stationed a small contingent of marines on a rusting World War II warship that was deliberately run aground on a submerged reef in the South China Sea.

title.children: Why a dilapidated wreck has become a flashpoint for conflict between China and the Philippines

image.altText: Wild Mushroom Death Cap

items.synopsis: The deaths of three Victorians after a Saturday lunch in the small town of Leongatha sent shock waves through the community, but also shone the spotlight on one of the most poisonous organisms on earth.

title.children: What happens when you eat a death cap mushroom?

image.altText: Graphic of Australian Bank logos on houses including Commonwealth, ANZ, Westpac, and National.

items.synopsis: The big banks were offering cashback deals and competitive rates to grab their share of the refinancing boom, but the trend has reversed as margins start to come under pressure, leaving some borrowers trapped between a mortgage cliff and a mortgage prison.

title.children: Why the honeymoon is over — banks pull back on fight for new borrowers

image.altText: Eight people in colonial-era garb on a longboat at sea.

items.synopsis: Riding horses for three days to get to a dance in the city, chasing kangaroos and jumping fences. An 1800s sketchbook reveals the unlikely life of a colonial woman.

title.children: Kate Mitchell died a horrific death, but her sketches of colonial life offer an 'honest' glimpse into history

image.altText: People walk through the front door of a house, past a For Lease sign.

items.synopsis: About 30 per cent of Australians live in rental accommodation with growing numbers in seats that helped secure government for Labor. But the Greens want to win those votes and next week's National Cabinet will offer clues as to how determined Labor is to stop them, writes David Speers.

title.children: Next week holds an important moment for housing policy — and renters are gaining influence

image.altText: Anthony Albanese walking on a red dirt road surrounded by people in body paint carrying red flags

items.synopsis: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander agencies, Voice to Parliament advocates and the prime minister have described a conspiracy theory on the length of the Uluru Statement from the Heart as a misinformation campaign to avoid debating the facts.

title.children: Voice to Parliament conspiracy theory an attempt to create 'misinformation and division'

image.altText: A female child star with a bob haircut, looks side-on to a camera with a vacant expression

items.synopsis: Lil Tay, whose real name is Claire Hope, made a name for herself by posting controversial but viral videos that involved a lot of profanity as well as designer clothes and luxury cars.

title.children: Child star Lil Tay, famed for controversial online videos, dies aged 14

image.altText: A man in a black shirt and scar, arrives at a premiere, smiling to photographers

items.synopsis: The Canadian-born Robertson was a high school dropout who fell in love with the seemingly limitless sounds and byways of his adopted US.

title.children: Robbie Robertson, lead guitarist and songwriter of The Band, dies at 80

image.altText: Matt Okine as Arthur and Denise Scott as Maggie with hands clasped together both smiling, one wearing blue, the other pink

items.synopsis: Actor, comedian and author Denise Scott tells the Australian Women's Weekly in an exclusive interview she was diagnosed with cancer immediately before she was due to start filming the Mother and Son remake.

title.children: Denise Scott opens up about filming Mother and Son while battling cancer

image.altText: Man holding a child walks across building debris on flooded ground

items.synopsis: As people in coastal China flee successive typhoons and parts of the Philippines are awash, can decades-old experiments to control the weather offer a way forward? Or is there a risk some countries may use weather as a new kind of weapon?

title.children: In the future, we could snuff out cyclones — but does it risk weather being used as a weapon?

image.altText: A charred boat lies in the scorched waterfront after wildfires

items.synopsis: Wildfires in Hawaii burn multiple structures and force evacuations from popular tourist areas, as rescuers pull a dozen people escaping smoke and flames from the ocean.

title.children: Six killed in Hawaii as wildfires force people to flee into ocean

image.altText: organe faced man with blonde hair

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Twitter fined $350k for failing to hand over Trump data: The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Health Minister Mark Butler says he has asked his department for advice over Hard Solo, a recently released alcoholic version of Solo softdrink. Butler tells ABC News Breakfast that he's "keen to talk" about the beverage, whose marketing strategies have raised concerns with some independent MPs. "Our general principle is quite clear, alcohol and products like that are for adults to consume in a responsible fashion. They should not be marketed to kids," he says. Federal crossbenchers will meet today with members of the alcohol industry, to discuss concerns around alcoholic drinks being marketed to underage drinkers and whether more regulation is needed. Independent MP Kylea Tink tells ABC News Breakfast that Hard Solo doesn't pass "the pub test". "We know young Australians have a particular taste for premixed drinks. Myself and my colleagues from the crossbench are meeting with the industry to really have that conversation of, 'Where is the line? And if this product isn't passing the pub test, what happens when a product crosses that line?'" "My main concern is the fact this product was approved through the self-regulatory environment. I think this is a clear breach of what the intention of that self-regulatory code is all about."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Health minister asks for advice over alcoholic Hard Solo, as crossbenchers meet with alcohol industry

children.content: Health Minister Mark Butler says he has asked his department for advice over Hard Solo
, a recently released alcoholic version of Solo softdrink.
Butler tells ABC News Breakfast that he's "keen to talk" about the beverage, whose marketing strategies have raised concerns with some independent MPs.
"Our general principle is quite clear, alcohol and products like that are for adults to consume in a responsible fashion. They should not be marketed to kids," he says.
Federal crossbenchers will meet today with members of the alcohol industry
, to discuss concerns around alcoholic drinks being marketed to underage drinkers and whether more regulation is needed.

props.alt: A blonde woman in a suit jacket gives a TV interview in front of a Canberra parliament house backdrop

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)
Independent MP Kylea Tink tells ABC News Breakfast that Hard Solo doesn't pass "the pub test".

"We know young Australians have a particular taste for premixed drinks. Myself and my colleagues from the crossbench are meeting with the industry to really have that conversation of, 'Where is the line? And if this product isn't passing the pub test, what happens when a product crosses that line?'"
"My main concern is the fact this product was approved through the self-regulatory environment. I think this is a clear breach of what the intention of that self-regulatory code is all about."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: World renowned singer Napua Greig lives on Maui and says she's never seen a fire like this. "We don't know how the fire started, the rumour on the ground is it was a downed electric line," she told ABC News Breakfast. "We've had really high gusts of wind in Maui in the past day which has made it extremely difficult for firefighters to fight the fire." "But we have had a string of fires being set by people, so we don't know yet if the fires are caused by natural causes or if the fires are intentionally set." Greig says a lot of the island is without power and many of the spots the island is famous for are now gone. "If you're familiar with the area, a lot of the areas that are iconic are now gone," she says. "Front Street which is where a lot of our visitors like to go and shop and dine on the waterfront, is now gone. "And everyone goes to have their dinner cruises and enjoy whale watching tours, it's now gone. "The iconic tree that sits in the middle of the town is gone, a church that houses many of the leaders of theHawaiian kingdom is now gone. "A lot of historic sites are no more." US President Joe Biden has just ordered all federal assets on the island to help with the fire response.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Maui fire victim and singer Napua Greig says island has 'never seen so much destruction'

props.alt: A close up of a woman with long dark hair

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast )
World renowned singer Napua Greig lives on Maui and says she's never seen a fire like this.
"We don't know how the fire started, the rumour on the ground is it was a downed electric line," she told ABC News Breakfast.
"We've had really high gusts of wind in Maui in the past day which has made it extremely difficult for firefighters to fight the fire."
"But we have had a string of fires being set by people, so we don't know yet if the fires are caused by natural causes or if the fires are intentionally set."
Greig says a lot of the island is without power and many of the spots the island is famous for are now gone.
"If you're familiar with the area, a lot of the areas that are iconic are now gone," she says.
"Front Street which is where a lot of our visitors like to go and shop and dine on the waterfront, is now gone.
"And everyone goes to have their dinner cruises and enjoy whale watching tours, it's now gone.
"The iconic tree that sits in the middle of the town is gone, a church that houses many of the leaders of theHawaiian kingdom is now gone.
"A lot of historic sites are no more."
US President Joe Biden has just ordered all federal assets on the island to help with the fire response.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Federal Health Minister Mark Butler has told ABC News Breakfast the government has given up on support from the Coalition but is talking to the cross bench about getting on board with its cheaper medicines measure. "We had fruitful discussions with the cross bench and the time for a decision is this morning," he says. "I think we've made the case about why this is a very sound policy around the world. "Pretty much every country we compare ourselves to, they allow 60- or 90-day scripts for these ongoing health conditions. It is supported by every patient group I can think of and every doctor's group." Butler says he does not agree with the Coalition that it's been rushed. "I've read the motion that the Coalition is moving this morning and it doesn't seek to delay it by six months. The motion is to disallow the measure and it would go altogether," he says. He says he doesn't believe it will negatively impact the pharmacy sector. "I said first of all we would reinvest every single dollar the Commonwealth saves from this measure which is about $1.2 billion, every single dollar back into the pharmacy sector and we would talk to pharmacies and crossbenchers and others about the best way to invest that money." You can read more on this story here:
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Health Minister determined to get 60-day script plan through parliament

featuredLink.title: Government scrambles to block Coalition's attempt to unwind half-price medication scheme

props.alt: Close up of Mark Butler on news breakfast

children.content: (ABC News Breakfast)

Federal Health Minister Mark Butler has told ABC News Breakfast the government has given up on support from the Coalition but is talking to the cross bench about getting on board with its cheaper medicines measure.
"We had fruitful discussions with the cross bench and the time for a decision is this morning," he says.
"I think we've made the case about why this is a very sound policy around the world.

"Pretty much every country we compare ourselves to, they allow 60- or 90-day scripts for these ongoing health conditions. It is supported by every patient group I can think of and every doctor's group."
Butler says he does not agree with the Coalition that it's been rushed.
"I've read the motion that the Coalition is moving this morning and it doesn't seek to delay it by six months. The motion is to disallow the measure and it would go altogether," he says.
He says he doesn't believe it will negatively impact the pharmacy sector.

"I said first of all we would reinvest every single dollar the Commonwealth saves from this measure which is about $1.2 billion, every single dollar back into the pharmacy sector and we would talk to pharmacies and crossbenchers and others about the best way to invest that money."
You can read more on this story here:

title.children: Legislation to establish parliament human resources agency tabled two years after sexual harassment review

items.synopsis: If pathologists start looking for CTE in the brains of domestic violence victims, will they find it? And what will it mean if they do?

title.children: The first female athlete with CTE was diagnosed in Australia — but there are roadblocks to testing domestic violence victims

image.altText: An Adelaide GP sits at her desk.

items.synopsis: Only about 15 per cent of medical students want to be GPs, but Australia needs about 40 per cent to specialise in general practice to solve the regional doctor shortage, a peak body says.

title.children: Push to raise 'prestige' of GPs from 'poor cousin' status to attract more regional doctors

image.altText: police tape down the side of a house

items.synopsis: Australian Defence Force personnel are travelling to Longreach to assess the object, found on a property once owned by late Queensland MP Vaughan Johnson.

title.children: Outback home under police guard after suspected World War II hand grenade found in yard

image.altText: A stylised graphic of the ASX board with an up arrow.

items.synopsis: Wall Street indices fall overnight but the Australian share market looks set to buck the trend and rise in early trade.

title.children: Wall Street falls, Australian market set to defy downward lead

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: European gas futures prices jumped 28% overnight, apparently mainly on news that there might be strikes at some of Western Australia's key gas export facilities. This from NAB's Rodrigo Catril : "Reuters notes that collectively monthly exports from the facilities equate to around 11% of exports globally, highlighting the risk of a supply squeeze as we head towards winter in the northern hemisphere. "The AFR noted about 99% of 180 production employees at Woodside's facilities voted for action, including indefinite strikes, and they shall be soon joined by hundreds of other employees at Chevron's facilities. "Strikes could start as early as next week."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australian LNG strike threat boosts European gas prices

children.content: European gas futures prices jumped 28% overnight, apparently mainly on news that there
might be strikes at some of Western Australia's key gas export facilities
This from
NAB's Rodrigo Catril

"Reuters notes that collectively monthly exports from the facilities equate to around 11% of exports globally, highlighting the risk of a supply squeeze as we head towards winter in the northern hemisphere.

"The AFR noted about 99% of 180 production employees at Woodside's facilities voted for action, including indefinite strikes, and they shall be soon joined by hundreds of other employees at Chevron's facilities.
"Strikes could start as early as next week."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The big result out of the US overnight was Disney, which was a mixed bag. The bright spot was 13% revenue growth for its theme parks, products and experiences division. However, the company lamented some disappointing box office results for films including Elemental and the latest Indiana Jones adventure. It also reported another drop in subscriber numbers for Disney+ to 146.1 million, down 7.4%, mainly due to the loss of broadcasting rights for Indian Premier League cricket. The relevant Disney+ Hotstar product lost 24% of its users. Earnings per share was slightly higher on an adjusted basis, while revenue was a touch lower than typical forecasts. The broadcaster took $US2.65 billion in one-time write-downs and charges, which dragged it to a $US460 million net loss.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Disney loses subscribers after missing out on Indian cricket rights

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Good morning, I'm joining you for a short while to take you through a couple of the company results that Dan flagged earlier. First up, AGL. It might be hard to believe that an electricity and gas company could possibly lose money given current power bills, but that's exactly what AGL did last year. It's reported a $1, 264 million net statutory loss for financial year 2023, which just ended on June 30. How did it lose so much money? There's two main reasons: It wrote down the value of its coal power plants by $680 million after deciding to close some of them earlier than previously planned. It lost $890 million from the value of various financial instruments, mostly futures contracts for electricity, after government intervention and market forces caused the wholesale price of power to drop dramatically late last year. AGL was stuck with contracts that were above the new market pricing. Excluding those write-downs, AGL's underlying net profit after tax was $281 million, up 25%. And if you think that still sounds small in a sector where retail prices have just jumped by around 20-30%, then don't worry, AGL is about to make up for it. It has reiterated its forecasts for an underlying net profit of between $580 and $780 million for the current 2024 financial year. That is somewhere between double and nearly triple this year's profit. As a 'gentailer' — a power generator who also retails to customers — AGL is benefitting from "sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing" and expected improved power plant availability, with less forced outages. However, it says inflation, difficulty collecting debts of some customers and increased maintenance spend will cap profit growth. This blog covered AGL's June announcement about its updated profit forecasts, below.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Energy company AGL posts $1.26 billion loss

featuredLink.title: AGL set to double profit as energy prices soar, ASX up, Wall Street rallies, Europe lifts rates — as it happened

And if you think that still sounds small in a sector where retail prices have just jumped by around 20-30%, then don't worry, AGL is about to make up for it.

That is somewhere between double and nearly triple this year's profit.

As a 'gentailer' — a power generator who also retails to customers — AGL is benefitting from "sustained periods of higher wholesale electricity pricing" and expected improved power plant availability, with less forced outages.
